awd_titl_txt: Analyzing and Supporting Students' Learning Behaviors in Computational STEM Learning Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Computational thinking (CT) is the foundation of modern competency in a multitude of STEM-related fields. Learning strategies influence the way a student processes information and learns, which in turn, requires the proper control and regulation of their cognitive processes. More specifically, an effective learning strategy requires students to have adequate descriptive, procedural, and conditional knowledge of the strategies they apply. This project will study the learning processes of middle school students when they are involved in learning science using a computational modeling approach. The research that will be performed will help us to better understand how to effectively integrate CT and computing into the K-12 science curricula. To examine how learning evolves, and the difficulties students face in developing and applying synergistic processes, a task-oriented framework will be developed to analyze student learning behaviors as they work on modeling and problem-solving tasks. 

This project will use adaptive scaffolding to synergistically teach scientific concepts with computational modeling to middle school students. Student learning behaviors will be analyzed using self-regulated learning theory. This project aims to make the following research contributions: (1) develop a framework for analyzing student learning behaviors and strategies as they are involved in their model building, model debugging, and problem solving tasks; (2) use a combination of students activity logs and eye tracking data to understand student cognitive and metacognitive processes as they work in the C2STEM environment; and (3) study the effectiveness of the adaptive scaffolding and feedback generation framework by analyzing how this helps students overcome their difficulties, and progress in their learning and problem solving tasks. An intelligent peer agent in an artificial intelligence system will be developed to achieve these goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In recent years, there has been a growing emphasis on implementing technology-enhanced learning environments in secondary school classrooms to support problem-based learning (PBL) in STEM fields. In our work, we have leveraged the connections between science and computing (C) to develop curricula that combine science, engineering, and computing concepts and practices. These curricula integrate authentic computational modeling of scientific processes with related problem-solving tasks. While these environments have shown promise in supporting learning across multiple domains, researchers have also noted that they can introduce additional complexity, exacerbating students’ difficulties in constructing and integrating knowledge during model-building tasks. We address these challenges by encouraging students to collaborate, explore, and develop ideas while constructing and evaluating their solutions for complex computational modeling tasks. Collaborative problem-solving (CPS) approaches have significantly enhanced student learning. Previous research has shown that collaboration fosters the development of shared knowledge and enhances problem-solving behaviors.

At Vanderbilt University, we have developed the Collaborative, Computational STEM (C2STEM) learning environment, accompanied by NGSS-aligned high school and middle school science and computing units. C2STEM adopts a learning-by-modeling paradigm and a visual programming framework that utilizes domain-specific modeling languages to support K-12 students' learning of science (e.g., Physics, Marine Biology, and Earth Sciences) by building computational models of scientific processes. Our research has demonstrated that the computational modeling paradigm has been successful in helping students learn science and computing concepts and practices synergistically.

We conducted studies using data from videos, speech, and activity logs to analyze how students learn while working on computational models and problem-solving tasks in the C2STEM learning environment. Although science and computational thinking (CT) share some common practices, there has been limited progress in integrating CT into K-12 science curricula. This project addresses the challenge of understanding how middle and high school students learn as they create computational models of scientific processes and apply them to problem-solving. One key achievement of our project is the application of Generative AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) to analyze students’ learning behaviors using the collected data. We aim to support student learning and provide teachers with insights to enhance their teaching methods.

Studying Collaborative Problem-Solving Behaviors. We have used multimodal learning analytics (MMLA) to study how students think, reflect, and collaborate while engaged in small-group computational tasks in STEM. Our research has focused on: (1) Improving understanding of collaborative problem-solving (CPS) behaviors in STEM+C learning; (2) Developing specific MMLA techniques to analyze student learning behaviors in detail; and (3) Investigating the connections between CPS behaviors, STEM+C learning, and problem-solving skills.

Automated Grading of Short-answer Questions with Feedback. Our team has partnered with teachers and students to enhance automated grading, providing feedback for short-answer assessments in earth sciences. We have developed a method for prompt engineering that utilizes a Chain-of-Thought Prompting plus Active Learning (CoTAL) approach to score and provide feedback across various subjects. This method improved the scoring accuracy of GPT-4 by up to 24.5%. Additionally, we developed an LLM-based chatbot to assist students in understanding their assessment scores, which received positive feedback during classroom testing.

AI for Pedagogical Support. Advances in AI and MMLA offer new ways to assist K-12 students in STEM+C learning. However, AI systems often struggle with understanding students’ emotions and social interactions. We created an AI-generated multimodal timeline to help teachers provide feedback and address student difficulties. A case study demonstrated the benefits of collaboration between teachers and AI, resulting in the development of teaching and peer agents within the C2STEM environment. Twelve design principles were identified to enhance collaborative learning.

Multimodal Analytics with Large Language Models (LLMs). Collaborative learning environments require analyzing various student behaviors, including their gaze, movements, speech, and activities. Traditional methods for analyzing these data are time-consuming and hard to scale. Recent advancements enable the automated analysis of students’ collaborative behaviors using multimodal data, vision-based AI algorithms, and LLMs. Our approach categorizes student behaviors linked to Self-Regulated Learning (SRL) and Socially Shared Regulation of Learning (SSRL). We achieved an overall classification accuracy of 81.3%, with the highest accuracy observed for enacting and interacting behaviors, at 93%. In contrast, planning, reflecting, and monitoring exhibited lower accuracies of 80%, 73%, and 68%, respectively.

This project has resulted in several publications. Our long-term goal is to help educators and stakeholders understand the value of integrating computational thinking into STEM learning and preparing students for the 21st-century workforce.
